docs.snippet: The United States began a military training exercise with Philippine soldiers today in an expansion of the Bush administration's war against terror aimed at stamping out a Muslim extremist group in the southern Philippines.    More than 100 Americ...
docs.lead_paragraph: The United States began a military training exercise with Philippine soldiers today in an expansion of the Bush administration's war against terror aimed at stamping out a Muslim extremist group in the southern Philippines. More than 100 American soldiers of an expected contingent of 600, including Special Forces, are already at the Philippine military headquarters in Zamboanga.
docs.abstract: United States begins military training exercise with Philippine soldiers in expansion of Bush administration's war against terrorism aimed at stamping out Abu Sayyaf, Muslim extremist group in southern Philippines; more than 100 American soldiers of expected contingent of 600 are at military headquarters in Zamboanga; photo (M)

headline.main: U.S. Troops Begin Exercises In Philippines

docs.snippet: FEW taboos exist in the blood-and-gore world of shoot-'em-up video games. But game makers have traditionally respected one rule: no Nazi protagonists.    Last year that rule was challenged on at least two fronts. In November, Activision released R...
docs.lead_paragraph: FEW taboos exist in the blood-and-gore world of shoot-'em-up video games. But game makers have traditionally respected one rule: no Nazi protagonists. Last year that rule was challenged on at least two fronts. In November, Activision released Return to Castle Wolfenstein, a game in which players take the role of a United States soldier on a mission ''to thwart Heinrich Himmler's occult and genetic experiments.'' The multiplayer version, which pits players against one another online, allows some players to fight as German soldiers.
docs.abstract: Video games like Return to Castle Wolfenstein and Day of Defeat break taboo on Nazi protagonists; swastikas and Nazi symbols are so pervasive in Day of Defeat that game might be viewed as illegal in Germany; game attracts many players with enthusiasm for neo-Nazi role playing, but programmers insist they are not interested in providing outlet for neo-Nazi sentiment (M)

headline.main: Defying a Taboo, Nazi Protagonists Invade Video Games

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: NAZI POLICIES TOWARD JEWS AND MINORITIES

docs.snippet: The airstrip at the United States naval base at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, is a busy place these days. No new prisoners are coming in from Afghanistan, at least for now, but many other visitors are arriving, in what looks increasingly like a salvage o...
docs.lead_paragraph: The airstrip at the United States naval base at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, is a busy place these days. No new prisoners are coming in from Afghanistan, at least for now, but many other visitors are arriving, in what looks increasingly like a salvage operation for America's reputation. Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld is to visit the prison camp at the base on Sunday to inspect conditions and review the treatment of Taliban and Qaeda prisoners. His visit comes as the camp is re-evaluating several of its procedures, including how long the prisoners have to wear blacked-out goggles, which the military has insisted are necessary to maintain tight security.
docs.abstract: Pentagon is flying in reporters from British, French, German and Australian news organization to observe prison camp for Taliban and Al Qaeda prisoners at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, naval base in face of intense criticism from allies about treatment and classification of prisoners; two Red Cross representatives are also on base; Sec Donald H Rumsfeld plans visit; photo (M)

headline.main: Criticized, U.S. Brings Visitors To Prison Camp

docs.snippet: Going beyond claims that the military tribunals authorized by President Bush would violate civil liberties guaranteed by American law, some experts are beginning to argue that they would breach international law guaranteeing fair treatment of pris...
docs.lead_paragraph: Going beyond claims that the military tribunals authorized by President Bush would violate civil liberties guaranteed by American law, some experts are beginning to argue that they would breach international law guaranteeing fair treatment of prisoners of war. Critics of the administration say the president's order authorizing the tribunals conflicts with treaties like the Geneva Conventions, which give P.O.W.'s facing charges of egregious conduct protections that include the right to choose their own lawyers, to be tried in courts that are independent of the prosecution and to appeal convictions. None of those rights are assured in the president's order, which opponents say precludes at least two of them.
docs.abstract: Critics of military tribunals authorized by Pres Bush say order not only violates US civil liberties but conflicts with treaties such as Geneva Convention, which guarantees certain defense and trial rights to prisoners of war; also see risks for armed forces, including war crimes charges against American officers by other countries; key issue is whether Bush means to declare that members of Taliban, Al Qaeda and other groups that support terrorists would not qualify for prisoner of war protections; Jordan J Paust says Bush unwittingly gives terrorists ability to claim that their attacks on military targets are lawful acts of combat; his photo (M)

headline.main: Critics' Attack On Tribunals Turns to Law Among Nations
headline.kicker: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE JUSTICE SYSTEM

docs.snippet: Faced with a deadline to cooperate with the United Nations war crimes tribunal or risk losing aid from the United States, Serbia's government approved a decree providing for the extradition of war crimes suspects to The Hague. The move came a day ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Faced with a deadline to cooperate with the United Nations war crimes tribunal or risk losing aid from the United States, Serbia's government approved a decree providing for the extradition of war crimes suspects to The Hague. The move came a day after Yugoslavia's constitutional court, dominated by Serbian nationalists, ruled that the tribunal's statute on extraditions cannot be applied in Serbia, which along with Montenegro makes up the Yugoslav federation. On Tuesday, Serbia met another demand for continued American aid by sending 146 ethnic Albanian prisoners in Serbian jails back to Kosovo. Eighty of those prisoners were freed yesterday, with the United Nations administrator of the province, Michael Steiner, saying that those who had committed crimes would remain imprisoned in Kosovo.
docs.abstract: Serbia, seeking to avoid losing United States aid, acts to allow extradition of war crimes suspects to The Hague; move comes after Yugoslavia's constitutional court rules that United Nations tribunal's statute on extraditions cannot be applied in Serbia (S)

headline.main: World Briefing | Europe: Serbia: Cooperation With Tribunal

docs.snippet: President Bush said today that he would push hard for a trade accord between the United States and Central America, but he also took time to criticize the Democrats back home for calling his four-day trip to Latin America an excuse to pander for L...
docs.lead_paragraph: President Bush said today that he would push hard for a trade accord between the United States and Central America, but he also took time to criticize the Democrats back home for calling his four-day trip to Latin America an excuse to pander for Latino votes. ''Sometimes in Washington, D.C., people cannot get rid of old habits,'' Mr. Bush said at a 30-minute news conference with President Francisco Flores. ''Which is petty politics, Mr. President. But that's just what happens.''
docs.abstract: Pres Bush says he will push hard for trade accord between US and Central America, but takes time during visit to El Salvador to criticize Democrats for calling four-day trip to Latin America excuse to pander for Latino votes; meets with Salvadoran Pres Francisco Flores, whom he lauds as democratic reformer and friend; says El Salvador, which decade ago was mired in violent civil war, is one of great stories of economic and political transformation of current era; criticisms of Bush trip by former California State Assembly speaker Antonio Villaraigosa, whose sees trip as part of orchestrated strategy to curry favor with Latinos, noted (M)

headline.main: In El Salvador, Bush Talks of Trade and Criticizes Democrats

docs.snippet: When Attorney General John Ashcroft announced the charges that 20-year-old John Walker will face in an American civilian court, it was the start of the public dance that comes in many public cases.     Prosecutors have their audiences, and Mr. Ash...
docs.lead_paragraph: When Attorney General John Ashcroft announced the charges that 20-year-old John Walker will face in an American civilian court, it was the start of the public dance that comes in many public cases. Prosecutors have their audiences, and Mr. Ashcroft played to his: the American public, people around the world and the defense in the case itself.
docs.abstract: Experts say Atty Gen John Ashcroft seeks to signal to American public, people around world and defense that prosecution has overwhelming evidence, based on John Walker's own words, that he conspired to kill Americans in Afghanistan and support terrorists; expect defense to reply publicly, offering hint of how it will portray Walker (M)

headline.main: Ashcroft's Message: Case Against Walker Is Solid
headline.kicker: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE LEGAL CASE

docs.snippet: ''Emergency!'' the men shouted as they jumped from a jeep outside the little clinic. A young nurse named Reina Malonzo hurried out to help, but they pushed by her in the rain and darkness and began smashing windows with their rifle butts.    They ...
docs.lead_paragraph: ''Emergency!'' the men shouted as they jumped from a jeep outside the little clinic. A young nurse named Reina Malonzo hurried out to help, but they pushed by her in the rain and darkness and began smashing windows with their rifle butts. They fired into the air. Their hostages, filthy and wet, stumbled into the little building and began taking showers and looking for fresh clothes.
docs.abstract: Abu Sayyaf, Muslim separatist group that terrorizes southern Philippines, has come under increasing suspicion as United States scours world for terrorists who might be linked to Osama bin Laden's Al Qaeda network or might aid its members; movement, which specializes in kidnappings for ransom, is linked to massacres, bombings, beheadings, rapes and forced 'marriages' with women they take hostage; former hostages describe treatment of American hostages Martin and Gracia Burnham; map; photos (M)

headline.main: Muslim Separatists Terrorize Filipinos With Kidnappings for Money and 'Marriages'

docs.snippet: With a week or so before the cherry blossoms burst, the spectrum of Americans braved cheek-scorching, near-freezing winds today to tour the Mall's hallowed grounds, where, come October, each step they take to the memorials, each gaze at the monume...
docs.lead_paragraph: With a week or so before the cherry blossoms burst, the spectrum of Americans braved cheek-scorching, near-freezing winds today to tour the Mall's hallowed grounds, where, come October, each step they take to the memorials, each gaze at the monuments, perhaps each crumb they toss the gulls in the reflecting pool will be watched and videotaped. Within six months, an official of the National Park Service told Congress today, the government plans to install a $2 million to $3 million closed-circuit television system at the Washington Monument and the Lincoln, Jefferson, Franklin D. Roosevelt, Vietnam and Korean War Memorials.
docs.abstract: National Park Service plans to install closed-circuit television system at Washington Monument and Lincoln, Jefferson, Franklin D Roosevelt, Vietnam and Korean War Memorials; visitors to Washington Mall voice willingness to exchange their long-enshrined right to privacy for personal safety; photos (L)

headline.main: For Security, Tourists to Be On Other Side Of Cameras

docs.snippet: Trapped by intense hostile fire and unable to evacuate their wounded for 12 hours, American Special Operations forces fought off an Al Qaeda ambush in some of the most grueling and gruesome combat of the five-month-old war in Afghanistan, official...
docs.lead_paragraph: Trapped by intense hostile fire and unable to evacuate their wounded for 12 hours, American Special Operations forces fought off an Al Qaeda ambush in some of the most grueling and gruesome combat of the five-month-old war in Afghanistan, officials said today. When it was over on Monday, the bodies of 7 American servicemen and 11 wounded comrades were lifted off the battlefield under guard of American combat aircraft. Their machine guns and cannon of AC-130's drove back the advancing fighters -- but not before commanders monitoring airborne surveillance video had seen Al Qaeda fighters dragging off an American serviceman to his death, military officials said.
docs.abstract: United States official describe grueling battle in which American Special Operations forces fought off Al Qaeda ambush in eastern Afghanistan after being trapped by intense fire for 12 hours, unable to evacuate wounded; say American forces returned to site where two helicopters were attacked while touching down after discovering that Navy Petty Officer Neil C Roberts had fallen from helicopter and watching him via airborne surveillance video being dragged off to his death by Al Qaeda fighters; say 7 Americans died and 11 were wounded in ambush of would-be rescuers; say hard-core Al Qaeda and Taliban fighters suffered heavy casualties while putting up surprisingly fierce resistance; senior officers predict remaining Al Qaeda and Taliban will be captured or killed in coming days; photos (M)

headline.main: A Nation Challenged: The Combat; U.S. Tells How Rescue Turned Into Fatal Firefight
